cont.entity_a: The N connection to desktop is problematic with constant dropped signals and lockups.
cont.entity_b: Wireless N devices do not connect.

cont.entity_a: Cisco is a known brand and the product looks well-made.
cont.entity_b: Linksys quality declined after Cisco acquisition.

cont.entity_a: The setup utility initially had trouble finding the router.
cont.entity_b: Setup wizard on CD didn't work with Windows XP; manual configuration required. Setup wizard with animated video simplifies installation.

cont.entity_a: Signal quality varies from excellent to good within an apartment, never losing IP settings.
cont.entity_b: Router has poor wireless range compared to WRT54.

cont.entity_a: Adding computers to the network requires running a Linksys program, which is good for security but annoying.
Router works well in a two-level house with range covering all rooms. The wireless range is less than expected, not covering a 2,700 sq. ft. brick house.
cont.entity_b: Router has less range than old Netgear Wireless-G router. Router has limited wireless range improvement over previous models.

cont.entity_a: Router came with a wrong power cord and had startup issues.
Initial wireless connection drops were resolved by adjusting frequency settings.

Performance.comm: Router performs well with DD-WRT firmware.

cont.entity_a: The router performs above average after flashing with DD-WRT firmware.
cont.entity_b: Router functions well as designed, with solid performance under DD-WRT.

cont.entity_a: Customer service was helpful and prompt in replacing a faulty unit.
The router works great, with a significant speed increase compared to the old G router.
cont.entity_b: Router is faster and eliminates dead spots compared to Wireless-G router.

cont.entity_a: Installation was straightforward using a wired connection and default IP address.
cont.entity_b: Router setup is easy with DHCP Reservation feature.

cont.entity_a: Router works well with direct connections but requires periodic reboots. Router works great but was quickly outdated. Router requires frequent reboots and eventually stopped working.
cont.entity_b: Router crashes occasionally, requiring reboots. Router died after 8 months, leading to a switch to Netgear. Router died after one week.

cont.entity_a: The reset button is inconveniently located, causing accidental resets.

Price.comm: Router works as advertised with a competitive price.

cont.entity_a: Router works great for a home network, but lacks range beyond 300 feet. Router provides good wireless range improvement.

Firmware.comm: Router requires firmware updates for optimal performance.

cont.entity_a: Router works well out of the box with updated firmware.
cont.entity_b: Router needs daily reboots with standard firmware; performs well with DD-WRT.

cont.entity_a: Router has poor build quality and frequent issues over time.
Router works well with advanced setup and support.
Linksys products have a reputation for dependability.

cont.entity_b: Router has many additional features with DD-WRT software.
Router's wireless storage feature does not work with NTFS formatted drives.
Router works well as a gigabit switch with DD-WRT firmware.

cont.entity_a: Router's wireless connection often requires power cycling to function.

cont.entity_b: Router's NAT function breaks, preventing internet connectivity.

cont.entity_a: Router is incompatible with SlingBox equipment.

cont.entity_b: Router is discontinued with no firmware support.
